title: Japan's Rugby World Cup heroes set for Twickenham date next autumn
text:
England are set to play Japan's World Cup heroes at Twickenham next year with the RFU in talks about staging an additional autumn international.

The weekend of November 21-22 has been earmarked for a fixture against the Brave Blossoms, who have captivated the sporting world with their rousing run to the quarter-finals.

The RFU have already announced games against New Zealand, Argentina and Australia for next November, but have one slot available for a match against a tier two nation which is set to go to Japan.

England are set to play Japan's Rugby World Cup heroes at Twickenham next year

Negotiations between the unions are understood to be at an advanced stage and the game could be finalised before the end of the World Cup.

England are already due to return to Japan next summer for a two-Test tour so could end up playing Jamie Joseph's side three times in six months, a stark contrast to the extremely limited history of matches between the two nations.

The two countries have only played twice at senior level, a 60-7 win for England in Sydney in 1987 followed 31 years later by a 35-15 victory for Eddie Jones's side at Twickenham last year.

The two countries have only met twice, including a 35-15 victory for England last November

Both unions are eager to capitalise on the success of this tournament, as are World Rugby, who are trying to encourage more matches between tier one and tier two nations in an attempt to help the latter progress.

Japan are also likely to seek entry to the Rugby Championship in the southern hemisphere alongside Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and Argentina, although that is complicated by the fact that those four unions have a new broadcast deal for 2021 to 2025 that does not involve Japan.
description: EXCLUSIVE BY MATT HUGHES IN TOKYO: England are set to play Japan's World Cup heroes at Twickenham next year with the RFU in talks about staging an additional autumn international.
authors: Matt Hughes For The Daily Mail
